questions.text: A pregnant female who is a known case of bronchial asthma presented to hospital with blood pressure of 160/100 mm Hg. Which of the following is the preferred drug for this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nifedipine

 

Considering the patient's condition of bronchial asthma, beta-blockers like labetalol and propranolol may not be the best choices due to the risk of exacerbating asthma. Nicardipine, a calcium channel blocker, is a safer alternative in this scenario. It effectively lowers blood pressure and is safe to use in pregnancy, without the risk of bronchoconstriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral Labetalol: Labetalol is a beta-blocker with alpha-blocking activity. It is commonly used for hypertension in pregnancy. However, being a beta-blocker, it can potentially exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction.

 

Option B. Intravenous Labetalol: This would be used for more immediate control of severely elevated blood pressure, like in a hypertensive crisis. The same concerns regarding bronchial asthma apply as with oral labetalol.

 

Option D. Propranolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker and is generally contraindicated in asthma because it can cause bronchoconstriction. It is also not the first choice for managing hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker is effective in lowering blood pressure and is generally considered safe in pregnancy. It does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects associated with beta-blockers.

questions.text: A patient on psychiatric medication developed a sudden hypertensive episode after consuming wine. Which of the following drugs is the person most likely taking? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MAO inhibitors

 

MAO inhibitors are likely the cause of the hypertensive episode after consuming cheese or wine. This class of drugs can interact with tyramine, a substance found in cheese and wine, leading to a hypertensive crisis. This is known as cheese reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amitriptyline: It is a tricyclic antidepressant. It doesn't cause hypertensive episodes in interaction with tyramine.

 

Option C. Fluoxetine: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), fluoxetine is not known to cause hypertensive crises due to tyramine interaction.

 

Option D. Trazodone: An antidepressant used for major depressive disorder and insomnia, trazodone is not associated with tyramine-induced hypertensive episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MAO inhibitors can cause hypertensive crises when patients consume foods high in tyramine, such as cheese and wine, due to the inhibition of tyramine breakdown, leading to its accumulation and subsequent hypertensive episodes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prostaglandin analogs

 

  • The clinical vignette suggests anterior uveitis with a raised intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like latanoprost increase uveoscleral outflow and lower intraocular pressure.
  • Prostaglandin analogues act by stimulating prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases that increase uveoscleral outflow.
  • Prostaglandin analogues should be used with caution in patients with uveitis, iritis, cystoid macular edema, and herpes simplex keratitis.
  • Prostaglandin analogues are the least suited for use in this patient as they can worsen the anterior uveitis.
  • PG Analogues can also cause cystoids macular edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta blockers: These are generally safe in uveitis unless contraindicated for systemic reasons.

 

Option B. Mannitol: This osmotic diuretic can be used for quick reduction of IOP in acute settings but does not exacerbate uveitis.

 

Option C. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors: Also safe for use in reducing IOP in uveitis, unless systemic contraindications exist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with anterior uveitis and high IOP, prostaglandin analogs should be avoided due to their potential to worsen intraocular inflammation and the risk of inducing or exacerbating cystoid macular edema. Other options such as beta blockers, mannitol, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors can be considered based on the individual patient's overall health and specific eye condition.

choices.text: The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure
The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure
The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure
Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation

questions.text: The true statement among the following is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Losartan acts as thromboxane A2 antagonist and inhibits platelet aggregation.

 

Losartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker. It binds to the AT1 receptor with high affinity. It is also a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor and attenuates platelet aggregation. All ARBs are avoided in moderate to severe renal impairment due to risk of development of hyperkalemia. Most ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic impairment also except LEO (Safe in Liver disease are Eprosartan and Olmesartan)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The dose of telmisartan should be reduced in severe renal failure but not in hepatic failure: Like all the ARBs, telmisartan is avoided in severe renal disease. Further, telmisartan is excreted by biliary secretion. So, dose of telmisartan should be reduced in mild to moderate hepatic failure. 

 

Option B. The dose of irbesartan should be reduced in case of severe hepatic failure and but not in renal failure: Irbesartan is avoided in both severe renal and hepatic disease.

 

Option C. The dose of olmisartan should be reduced in severe liver failure as well as in renal failure: Olmesartan require dose adjustment in severe renal failure. However, olmesartan and eprosartan do not require dose adjustment even in severe liver failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All ARBs should be avoided in moderate to severe renal disease due to risk of hyperkalemia. Except Olmesartan and Eprosartan, all other ARBs require dose adjustment in moderate to severe hepatic disease also. Losartan has additional antiplatelet action by acting as TXA2 receptor antagonist.

questions.text: NAPQI is the metabolite of which of the following drug toxicity? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Paracetamol


N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a metabolite of paracetamol drug toxicity.

 

NAPQI is highly reactive and has high affinity for sulfydryl groups. It causes enzymatic dysfunction in the liver. Normally, minor amounts of NAPQI produced in our body are rapidly eliminated by conjugation with reduced glutathione (GSH) that acts as a source of sulfhydryl group and then excreted into the urine.

 

Therefore, paracetamol toxicity is treated with N-acetyl cysteine (NAC), which provides the sulfhydryl group. NAC thereby helps in the excretion of NAPQI from the body.

 

The maximum recommended dose of acetaminophen is 4g/day.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Aspirin overdose primarily causes metabolic acidosis, respiratory alkalosis, and can lead to salicylate poisoning.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac toxicity does not involve NAPQI. Diclofenac is an NSAID that can cause gastrointestinal and renal toxicity.

 

Option D. Ketorolac: Ketorolac toxicity is not associated with NAPQI. Like other NSAIDs, ketorolac can cause gastrointestinal bleeding and renal toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NAPQI is a toxic metabolite produced during the metabolism of paracetamol. In cases of paracetamol overdose, NAPQI accumulates and causes liver damage. The antidote for paracetamol toxicity is N-acetylcysteine (NAC), which helps detoxify NAPQI by replenishing glutathione and providing sulfhydryl groups.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-dyslipidemic drug work by stimulating Peroxisome proliferator activated receptor (PPAR) alpha? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gemfibrozil

 

  • Fibrates are a class of hypolipidemic drugs.

  • They include Gemfibrozil, Fenofibrate, Clofibrate.

  • They are mainly used in Hypertriglyceridemia and chylomicronemia syndromes.

  • Fibrates bind to the PPAR alpha and stimulates Lipoprotein lipase thus enhancing the clearance of VLDL.

  • Their important side effects include: Gallstones formation and Myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atorvastatin: Atorvastatin is a statin, which is an HMG-CoA reductase inhibitor. It works by inhibiting the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, a key enzyme in the biosynthesis of cholesterol in the liver, leading to reduced levels of LDL cholesterol.

 

Option C. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe decreases the absorption of cholesterol from the small intestine. It targets and inhibits the Niemann-Pick C1-Like 1 (NPC1L1) protein, which is involved in the uptake of cholesterol.

 

Option D. Niacin: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, works by decreasing hormone-sensitive lipase activity, which leads to reduced breakdown of fats in adipose tissue. This decreases the levels of free fatty acids available for hepatic triglyceride synthesis, leading to lower levels of LDL and VLDL and an increase in HDL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrates, including gemfibrozil, work by stimulating PPAR-α, which enhances the activity of lipoprotein lipase, leading to increased clearance of VLDL and triglycerides. This mechanism makes fibrates particularly effective in treating hypertriglyceridemia and related disorders. Other hypolipidemic drugs like atorvastatin, ezetimibe, and niacin have different mechanisms of action targeting other aspects of lipid metabolism.

questions.text: Non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in all of the following conditions except? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Male infertility

 

Pulsatile exposure to GnRH induces FSH/LH secretion while sustained exposure de-sensitizes the receptors resulting in decrease in secretion of gonadotropins. Therefore, non-pulsatile (continuous) GnRH agonists are given when we want to decrease the sex hormones.

 

Indications:-

 

  •  Prostatic carcinoma
  •  Endometriosis
  •  Precocious puberty
  •  Fibroid

 

But in case of male infertility, more testosterone is required to induce spermatogenesis, so GnRH agonists are given in pulsatile manner.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: In endometriosis, continuous GnRH agonists are used to lower estrogen levels, which helps reduce the growth of endometrial tissue and alleviate symptoms.

 

Option C. Central precocious puberty: Continuous GnRH agonists are used to decrease sex hormone levels, thereby delaying early onset puberty.

 

Option D. Prostate cancer: Continuous GnRH agonists reduce testosterone levels, which helps in managing prostate cancer by slowing down the growth of cancer cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Non-pulsatile (continuous) GnRH agonists are used to decrease sex hormone levels in conditions such as endometriosis, central precocious puberty, and prostate cancer. In male infertility, pulsatile GnRH agonists are used to increase testosterone and induce spermatogenesis.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 262,263

choices.text: Ejaculation
Dilation of bronchus
Increased cardiac contractility

questions.text: Muscarinic receptor stimulation primarily causes which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Erection

 

  • Parasympathetic (muscarinic) stimulation result in erection whereas sympathetic stimulation causes ejaculation.
  • Parasympathetic system causes bronchoconstriction whereas sympathetic system result in bronchodilation.
  • Increase in cardiac contractility is primarily action of beta 1 receptors of the heart.

 

Mnemonic

 

Point and Shoot:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ejaculation: Ejaculation is primarily mediated by the sympathetic nervous system, not the parasympathetic system. Thus, muscarinic receptor stimulation does not cause ejaculation.

 

Option C. Dilation of bronchus: The parasympathetic system causes bronchoconstriction. Bronchodilation is mediated by the sympathetic nervous system.

 

Option D. Increased cardiac contractility: Increased cardiac contractility is primarily an action of beta-1 adrenergic receptors, which are part of the sympathetic nervous system. Muscarinic receptor stimulation generally results in decreased heart rate and contractility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscarinic receptor stimulation is associated with parasympathetic responses such as erection, while sympathetic stimulation is responsible for ejaculation, bronchodilation, and increased cardiac contractility.

questions.text: A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Outer hair cells

 

  • Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL) causes damage to outer hair cells.
  • NIHL Hearing loss, in this case, is due to chronic exposure.
  • It can be of two types
     
    1. Temporary threshold shift (TTS). The hearing is impaired immediately after exposure to noise but recovers after an interval of a few minutes to a few hours even up to 2 weeks
    2. Permanent threshold shift (PTS). The hearing impairment is permanent and does not recover at all.

 

The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch, at 4 kHz, both for air and bone conduction. This is referred to as acoustic dip or Boiler's notch.

 

 

The damage caused by noise trauma depends on several factors:

 

  1. Frequency of noise. A frequency of 2000–3000 Hz causes more damage than lower or higher frequencies.
  2. Intensity and duration of noise. As the intensity increases, permissible time for exposure is reduced.
  3. Continuous noise is more harmful.
  4. Susceptibility of the individual. Degree of TTS and PTS varies in different individuals.
  5. Pre-existing ear disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crista ampullaris: This structure is located within the semicircular canals of the inner ear and is primarily involved in sensing rotational movements of the head, not in hearing. Thus, it is not typically affected by noise-induced hearing loss.

 

Option B. Macula: Found in the utricle and saccule of the vestibular system, the macula detects linear accelerations and head tilts but is not directly involved in the auditory response to sound waves.

 

Option C. Cupola: The cupola is a gelatin-like structure in the vestibular system's semicircular canals that responds to changes in head position. Like the crista ampullaris, it is unrelated to the hearing process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noise-induced hearing loss specifically damages the outer hair cells in the cochlea, leading to hearing impairment.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 36, 37

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with chin protrusion, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance, and hand and foot enlargement. What is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pegvisomant

 

The patient's symptoms suggest acromegaly, a condition characterized by excessive growth hormone (GH) secretion, usually due to a pituitary adenoma. Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It blocks the effects of growth hormone at the receptor level, leading to decreased levels of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), which is responsible for the acromegaly symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Octreotide: Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue, which can be used in the treatment of acromegaly. It works by inhibiting the release of growth hormone from the pituitary gland. However, it is not a growth hormone receptor antagonist; instead, it reduces GH secretion.

 

Option C. Cabergoline: Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist primarily used in the treatment of prolactinomas, another type of pituitary adenoma. It is not typically used as a first-line treatment for acromegaly and does not act as a growth hormone receptor antagonist.

 

Option D. Olcegepant: Olcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide receptor antagonist used in the research for migraine treatment. It is not used in the treatment of acromegaly or related to growth hormone activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat acromegaly by blocking the effects of growth hormone at the receptor level, thereby reducing the symptoms associated with elevated growth hormone levels.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis? (Fmge July 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythromycin

 

Erythromycin is not typically used in the treatment of bacterial vaginosis. It is an antibiotic more commonly used for respiratory infections and certain skin infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metronidazole: This is drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option B. Tinidazole: Similar to metronidazole, tinidazole is also effective against bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is another antibiotic that can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythromycin is not typically used for bacterial vaginosis, whereas metronidazole, tinidazole, and clindamycin are effective treatments for this condition due to their efficacy against anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DNA gyrase inhibition

 

The description of a drug causing tendon rupture and arthropathy, especially in the context of treating a urinary tract infection, points towards a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin, work by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are essential for bacterial DNA replication and transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ribosomal Inhibition: Antibiotics that inhibit ribosomes, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, and aminoglycosides, affect protein synthesis. These drugs are not typically associated with tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Option C. Cell Wall Synthesis Inhibition: Drugs that inhibit cell wall synthesis, like beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins) and vancomycin, are not known to cause tendon rupture or arthropathy as a common side effect.

 

Option D. Inhibition of Folic Acid Synthesis: Antibiotics that inhibit folic acid synthesis, such as sulfonamides and trimethoprim, do not typically cause tendon rupture or arthropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluoroquinolones, which inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, are associated with serious side effects such as tendon rupture and arthropathy.

choices.text: It acts as a calcium chelator and reduces the availability of calcium in coagulation pathway
It binds and activates anti-thrombin 3 that accelerates its interaction with thrombin and factor Xa resulting in their degradation
It acts as a Vitamin K inhibitor that leads to inhibition of activation of clotting factors 2,7,9 and 10
It inhibits tissue plasminogen activator resulting in stoppage of conversion of plasminogen to plasmin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding mechanism of action of dicumarol? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It acts as a Vitamin K inhibitor that leads to inhibition of activation of clotting factors 2,7,9 and 10
 

The mechanism of action of dicumarol is similar to that of Warfarin. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme - Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (VKOR), which is necessary for activation of the clotting factors 2, 7, 9 and 10 by Gamma Carboxylation of their glutamate residues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as a calcium chelator and reduces the availability of calcium in the coagulation pathway: This describes the mechanism of action of EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid), which is used in laboratory settings to prevent blood clotting by chelating calcium, a necessary cofactor in the coagulation cascade.

 

Option B. It binds and activates anti-thrombin 3 that accelerates its interaction with thrombin and factor Xa resulting in their degradation: This describes the mechanism of action of heparin. Heparin enhances the activity of antithrombin III, leading to the inactivation of thrombin and factor Xa, thus preventing clot formation.

 

Option D. It inhibits tissue plasminogen activator resulting in stoppage of conversion of plasminogen to plasmin: This describes the mechanism of action of antifibrinolytic agents such as tranexamic acid or epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA), which inhibit tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) and prevent the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby inhibiting fibrinolysis and stabilizing clots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dicumarol acts as a Vitamin K inhibitor, preventing the activation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X by inhibiting the enzyme Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (VKOR). This inhibition is crucial for its anticoagulant effect, similar to that of warfarin.

questions.text: A patient is found on a railway track with hot dry skin, raised temperature, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dhatura poisoning

 

The patient presents with several characteristic signs and symptoms: hot dry skin, raised temperature (hyperthermia), dilated pupils (mydriasis), slurred speech, and staggering gait. These symptoms are indicative of anticholinergic poisoning, and specifically point towards Dhatura poisoning.

 

Dhatura (Datura) is a plant that contains tropane alkaloids, such as atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine, which have strong anticholinergic effects.

 

These effects include: (Mnemonic DHATURA)

 

  • Dryness of skin and mucous membranes (due to inhibition of sweat and salivary glands).
  • Hyperthermia (elevated body temperature) because of decreased sweating.
  • Mydriasis (Dilated pupils), leading to photophobia and blurred vision.
  • Agitation
  • Tachycardia.
  • Urinary Retention and loss of accommodation (difficulty focusing).
  • Accommodation loss – Blurred Vision

 

Slurred speech and staggering gait can also be observed due to central nervous system effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alcohol intoxication: While slurred speech and a staggering gait are common in alcohol intoxication, alcohol typically causes hypothermia (lowered body temperature), not hyperthermia. Also, alcohol intoxication generally does not cause hot, dry skin or dilated pupils.

 

Option C. Opioid overdose: This usually presents with pinpoint pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and unconsciousness, not dilated pupils, hyperthermia, or dry skin.

 

Option D. Cocaine poisoning: Cocaine can cause hyperthermia and dilated pupils, but it typically results in increased activity and agitation rather than the slurred speech and staggering gait associated with Dhatura poisoning. Additionally, the dry skin is more characteristic of anticholinergic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dhatura poisoning is characterized by anticholinergic symptoms such as hot dry skin, hyperthermia, dilated pupils, slurred speech, and a staggering gait, distinguishing it from other causes of altered mental status.

questions.text: A young patient began taking a weight loss medication that works by preventing fat absorption from food. She developed easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding after a few weeks. Which of the following vitamins deficiency is likely to be responsible for her condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin K

 

  • Vitamin A, D, E and K are fat soluble vitamins. Their absorption is hampered when the absorption of fat is prevented by a medication (eg Orlistat , Ezetimibe etc).
  • Vitamin K is required for the Gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of clotting factors 2 ,7 ,9 and 10 in order to activate them. If Vitamin K is deficient due to fat malabsorption, as in the above case, then there can be bleeding manifestations in the form of easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding in females. The Prothrombin Time (PT) will be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency can manifest as hemolytic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6: Vitamin B6 deficiency can be seen with drugs like Isoniazid, Penicillamine, Hydralazine, OCP. Patients can have peripheral neuritis, lowered seizure threshold, or convulsions.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to the development of rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin K deficiency due to impaired fat absorption from weight loss medications can lead to bleeding manifestations such as easy bruising and increased menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with a diagnosis of schizophrenia was started on an antipsychotic medication. Within a few weeks, he developed symptoms of Parkinsonism, such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and a shuffling gait. The medical team is considering prescribing an additional medication to manage these extrapyramidal side effects. Which of the following drugs can be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trihexyphenidyl

 

Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic medication commonly used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms like Parkinsonism that may arise as a side effect of antipsychotic medications. It can counteract the dopamine antagonism caused by antipsychotic drugs, thereby alleviating symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entacapone: Entacapone is a COMT inhibitor used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease to prolong the action of levodopa. It's not typically used to treat drug-induced Parkinsonism.

 

Option C. Rasagiline: Rasagiline is a monoamine oxidase type B (MAO-B) inhibitor used primarily in Parkinson's disease. It's not commonly used for drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Pramipexole: Pramipexole is a dopamine agonist also used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease but is ineffective in treatment of extrapyramidal symptoms induced by antipsychotic medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trihexyphenidyl is the appropriate medication for managing extrapyramidal side effects, such as Parkinsonism, induced by antipsychotic medications. It works by counteracting the dopamine antagonism and restoring the balance between acetylcholine and dopamine in the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

Amiodarone is a class III anti arrhythmic drug. One of the adverse effects of amiodarone that is seen with long term therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive. Therefore, it is contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

The other adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism (Amiodarone is 40% iodine by weight), blue grey skin pigmentation, corneal deposits, constipation and bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sotalol: Sotalol is also a class III antiarrhythmic agent but does not have the same risk of pulmonary toxicity as amiodarone. It is generally considered safer for patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

Option C. Quinidine: Quinidine is a class I antiarrhythmic drug that is not associated with pulmonary toxicity. It has other potential side effects but is not contraindicated in interstitial lung disease.

 

Option D. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (lidocaine) is a class Ib antiarrhythmic agent primarily used for ventricular arrhythmias. It does not have pulmonary toxicity and is not contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease due to its potential to cause pulmonary fibrosis, a serious and potentially irreversible adverse effect. It is essential to consider this risk when prescribing antiarrhythmic therapy to patients with pre-existing lung conditions.

questions.text: Preferred drug for the treatment of a 48-year-old man with uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension without any associated co-morbidity is (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chlorthalidone

 

  • Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that is highly effective in lowering blood pressure and is often recommended as the preferred first-line treatment for uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension. It has a longer duration of action compared to other thiazides, such as hydrochlorothiazide, making it particularly effective in managing hypertension over a 24-hour period.
  • According to ACC Guidelines and JNC 8 Guidelines, the DOC for hypertension is Thiazides (preferred diuretic).
  • Apart from thiazides, the other first line drugs for hypertension are-
  • ACE Inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triamterene: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It is primarily used in combination with other diuretics to prevent hypokalemia but is not recommended as a first-line treatment for hypertension.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: Another potassium-sparing diuretic, primarily used in conditions such as heart failure, hyperaldosteronism, and resistant hypertension, not as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension.

 

Option D. Furosemide: This is a loop diuretic, which is typically used in conditions such as congestive heart failure, renal insufficiency, and edema. It is not recommended as a first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension due to its short duration of action and the potential for significant electrolyte disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the treatment of uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension without any associated comorbidities, thiazide diuretics, particularly chlorthalidone, are the preferred first-line agents according to ACC and JNC 8 guidelines.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/615

questions.text: A pediatric patient is brought to the emergency department with signs of ocular hypotension and apnea. The parents are concerned about the child's condition and have provided a history of recent medication use. It is crucial to determine which drug may have caused these symptoms in the infant. Drug capable of causing ocular hypotension with apnea in infants is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brimonidine

 

Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to lower intraocular pressure in conditions such as glaucoma. It acts by decreasing the production of aqueous humor and increasing its outflow, thereby reducing intraocular pressure. While brimonidine is generally well-tolerated, it can have systemic side effects, particularly in infants. The most concerning systemic side effect in this context is central nervous system depression, which can manifest as symptoms like apnea (temporary cessation of breathing). Infants, especially premature ones, are more susceptible to such side effects. Therefore, brimonidine is the drug most likely responsible for causing ocular hypotension with apnea in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker commonly used to lower intraocular pressure. While it can have systemic side effects, including bradycardia and bronchospasm, it is not typically associated with apnea in infants.

 

Option C. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor. It can cause side effects such as changes in iris color and eyelash growth. However, it is not known to cause apnea in infants.

 

Option D. Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in ophthalmology to reduce intraocular pressure. While it can cause ocular hypotension, it is not a common cause of apnea, especially in infants.

questions.text: A man with diabetes was on medication and forgot to take his meals before going to the gym. During his workout, he collapsed, and his blood sugar level was found to be 50 mg/dL. Which of the following oral antidiabetic drugs can result in hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glimepiride

 

Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea, a class of oral antidiabetic drugs known to stimulate insulin release from pancreatic beta cells. This action can lead to a decrease in blood glucose levels, which, if not balanced with adequate food intake, can result in hypoglycemia. The patient's low blood sugar level (50 mg/dL) and the scenario of collapsing during a workout indicate that hypoglycemia occurred, likely due to the effect of glimepiride.

 

[Mnemonic: any drug which ends with “ide” can cause hypoglycemia, except glutides (liraglutide), axenatide]

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that primarily decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity. It does not usually cause hypoglycemia when used as monotherapy because it does not stimulate insulin secretion.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that increases incretin levels, which in turn increases insulin release and decreases glucagon levels. However, it does not generally cause hypoglycemia as monotherapy because its action is glucose-dependent.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that increases insulin sensitivity but does not stimulate insulin release. Thus, it does not typically cause hypoglycemia when used alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sulfonylureas, like glimepiride, can cause hypoglycemia, especially when meals are skipped, due to their insulin-stimulating effects.

choices.text: Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

questions.text: Mechanism of thalidomide teratogenicity include all except
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in IL-2, IL-4 and IL-5

 

Thalidomide actually suppresses the production of certain cytokines, including IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5. The suppression of these interleukins is part of its immunomodulatory effects, not a mechanism of teratogenicity. Thalidomide suppresses the production of interleukins which is an important mechanism in treatment of multiple myeloma.

 

The exact mechanism of thalidomide's teratogenicity is not completely understood, but several mechanisms have been proposed:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of angiogenesis: Thalidomide has been found to inhibit angiogenesis, which is the formation of new blood vessels. This inhibition can disrupt the development of the fetus, leading to birth defects. This mechanism is widely accepted as a significant contributor to the teratogenic effects of thalidomide.

 

Option C. Generation of oxygen free radicals: Thalidomide may cause oxidative stress by generating oxygen free radicals, which can damage developing cells. This oxidative stress can contribute to teratogenic effects.

 

Option D. Binding to cereblon: Recent studies have shown that thalidomide binds to a protein called cereblon, which is involved in limb outgrowth and ear development. When thalidomide binds to cereblon, it disrupts the normal function of this protein, leading to the birth defects associated with thalidomide use.

 

Other mechanism includes -

 

  • Interference with cellular signalling: Thalidomide may interfere with various cellular signalling pathways, such as those involving fibroblast growth factors, which are important for embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thalidomide's teratogenicity is primarily associated with mechanisms such as the inhibition of angiogenesis, generation of oxygen free radicals, and binding to the cereblon protein. It does not cause an increase in IL-2, IL-4, and IL-5; in fact, it suppresses these interleukins.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient underwent surgery under general anaesthesia. Rocuronium was used as a muscle relaxant during the procedure. After the surgery, the patient has not regained muscle function, indicating prolonged muscle paralysis. The medical team needs to reverse the effects of rocuronium quickly to ensure patient safety and recovery. Which of the following can result in the fastest reversal? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sugammadex

 

  • Sugammadex is a specific reversal agent for aminosteroid neuromuscular blocking agents such as rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating the rocuronium molecules, rendering them inactive, and thus rapidly reversing the neuromuscular blockade. Sugammadex provides the fastest and most effective reversal of rocuronium-induced paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, competing with rocuronium. While effective, it is slower and less specific than sugammadex and can have more side effects.

 

Option C. Edrophonium: Edrophonium is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor but is less commonly used compared to neostigmine for reversing neuromuscular blockade. It is generally faster than neostigmine but still not as rapid or effective as sugammadex for rocuronium reversal.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade. It is an anticholinergic agent primarily used to counteract the muscarinic side effects of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine and edrophonium, such as bradycardia. It does not reverse muscle paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, sugammadex is the most effective and fastest-acting agent for reversing the effects of rocuronium, making it the best choice in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with chest pain and shortness of breath. Further investigation reveals a mediastinal mass on imaging studies. The patient is referred to a specialist for further evaluation. What is the most common type of tumor found in the anterior mediastinum? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

The most common anterior mediastinal tumor is thymoma, while posterior mediastinal tumor is neurogenic tumor.

 

The most common mediastinal tumor in children is neurogenic tumor.

 

  • Thymomas are tumors that originate from the thymus gland located in the mediastinum.
  • They account for a significant portion of mediastinal tumors and are the most common type.
  • Thymomas can vary in terms of malignancy, with some being benign (noncancerous) and others being malignant (cancerous).
  • These tumors can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and other symptoms when they grow and press on nearby structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurogenic: Neurogenic tumors, which originate from nerve tissue, are another type of mediastinal tumor found in posterior mediastinum

 

  • Examples of neurogenic tumors include neuroblastoma and ganglioneuroma.

 

Option C. Lymphoma: Lymphomas can occur in the mediastinum but are less frequent than thymomas.

 

  • Lymphomas originate from lymphatic tissue and can be Hodgkin lymphoma or non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option D. Bronchial cyst: Bronchial cysts are fluid-filled sacs that can develop in the mediastinum but are relatively rare compared to thymomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, thymoma is the most common type of tumor found in the mediastinum, and it originates from the thymus gland. When a patient presents with chest pain and shortness of breath and is found to have a mediastinal mass on imaging studies, thymoma is a likely consideration among other possible mediastinal tumors

questions.text: Which drug is used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by daunorubicin? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexrazoxane

 

Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent used specifically to prevent cardiotoxicity associated with anthracycline chemotherapy agents like daunorubicin. It protects the heart by reducing the formation of free radicals that can damage cardiac tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aprepitant: Aprepitant is utilized to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by chemotherapy. It works as a neurokinin-1 receptor antagonist but does not have a role in preventing cardiotoxicity from chemotherapeutic drugs.

 

Option C. Amifostine: Amifostine is a cytoprotective agent that offers protection against the toxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation therapy on normal tissues, particularly for kidneys and salivary glands, but it is not indicated for the prevention of cardiotoxicity from daunorubicin.

 

Option D. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. In oncology, it is often used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and to treat certain cancer-related conditions, but it is not used to prevent daunorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexrazoxane is specifically used to prevent cardiotoxicity induced by anthracycline chemotherapy agents such as daunorubicin by reducing free radical formation and oxidative stress on the heart.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the receptors they act upon: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

 

 

Other Options:

 

A-3. Mirabegron acts on β3 receptors. Mirabegron is a β3 adrenergic receptor agonist used for the treatment of bladder incontinence by relaxing the detrusor muscle during the storage phase of the urinary bladder fill-void cycle.

 

B-4. Indacaterol acts on β2 receptors. Indacaterol is a long-acting β2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

 

C-1. Betaxolol acts on β1 receptors. Betaxolol is a β1 selective blocker used in the treatment of hypertension and glaucoma.

 

D-2. Isoproterenol acts on β1 β2 receptors. Isoproterenol is a non-selective β adrenergic agonist with no α action, used in the treatment of bradycardia and heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Matzke scale
Salazar scale
Rummack-mathew scale

questions.text: Vancomycin nomogram is known as (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Matzke scale

 

The Vancomycin nomogram is also known as the Matzke nomogram or the Matzke scale. It is a tool used to help predict the appropriate dose of vancomycin, an antibiotic, based on the patient's creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration. The nomogram is a graphical representation that allows healthcare providers to quickly and easily determine the optimal dose of vancomycin for a given patient, taking into account factors such as kidney function and the patient's weight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salazar scale: This nomogram is not related to vancomycin dosing. It is used to predict overall survival of patients with cancer.

 

Option C. Rummack-Matthew scale: This is used to assess potential hepatotoxicity after acetaminophen intake based on serum acetaminophen concentration.

 

Option D. Krutzko scale: There is no widely recognized medical scale or nomogram known as the Krutzko scale.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vancomycin nomogram, also known as the Matzke scale, is a crucial tool for determining the appropriate dosing of vancomycin based on creatinine clearance and trough serum concentration, ensuring both efficacy and safety in patient treatment.

questions.text: A patient was given digoxin. He started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4 mg/dL. The plasma therapeutic range is 1 mg/dL. If the half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long one should wait before resuming the treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 80 hours

 

To determine how long it will take for the patient's serum digoxin concentration to decrease to a therapeutic level (1 mg/dL) from 4 mg/dL, we need to consider the drug's half-life. The half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, which means that every 40 hours, the concentration of the drug in the plasma will be reduced by half.

 

  • Initial concentration: 4 mg/dL
  • Therapeutic concentration: 1 mg/dL
  • Half-life of digoxin: 40 hours

 

We can use the concept of half-lives to calculate the time needed:

 

  1. After the first half-life (40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 4 mg/dL to 2 mg/dL.
  2. After the second half-life (another 40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 2 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL.

 

Therefore, it will take 80 hours for the digoxin concentration to fall from 4 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL, which is within the therapeutic range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient experiencing side effects from digoxin with a serum concentration of 4 mg/dL, wait 80 hours (two half-lives) for the concentration to decrease to the therapeutic range before resuming treatment.

questions.text: A patient presented with ptosis which gets worsened by evening. He was diagnosed to be a case of myasthenia gravis. What is the preferred treatment of this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyridostigmine

 

Pyridostigmine is the preferred initial treatment for myasthenia gravis. It is effective in improving muscle strength by inhibiting the breakdown of acetylcholine, thereby increasing its availability at the neuromuscular junction. Other options like plasma exchange and cyclosporine are typically reserved for more severe cases or when standard treatments fail. Physostigmine is not commonly used for myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasma Exchange: This is used in myasthenia gravis, particularly in cases of myasthenic crisis or before surgery. It's an acute treatment method rather than a long-term management strategy.

 

Option B. Cyclosporine: This is an immunosuppressant used in the treatment of myasthenia gravis, usually in cases where patients do not respond to first-line treatments or as an adjunct therapy.

 

Option D. Physostigmine: Unlike pyridostigmine, physostigmine is not commonly used for myasthenia gravis because of its central adverse effects. It is a lipid soluble cholinesterase inhibitor and is mainly used in atropine poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor and is the mainstay of treatment for myasthenia gravis. It helps increase the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving muscle strength.

questions.text: A young male patient has been on 5 mg haloperidol for several days. However, he has been experiencing inner restlessness and a strong want to move for the past four days. The most likely diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Akathisia

 

The patient is presenting with inner restlessness and a compelling desire to be in constant motion, which is consistent with akathisia. This is a common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medications like haloperidol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia: Tardive dyskinesia is a late-onset extrapyramidal side effect that can present as involuntary, repetitive movements of the tongue (e.g., twisting, protrusion), jaw (e.g., chewing also called. 

 

Option C. Rabbit syndrome: Rabbit syndrome lips (e.g., smacking, puckering), trunk and extremities.

 

Option D. Acute dystonia: Acute dystonia is the earliest side effect of antipsychotic and is characterized by sudden onset of muscle spasms, typically in the head and neck, occurring within hours to days of drug initiation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Akathisia is characterized by a sense of inner restlessness along with objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time. They can present soon after starting the antipsychotic or after dosage adjustments. It is the most common extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics. Drug of choice is Propranolol (beta blockers).

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 114

questions.text: Ohngren's classification and Ohngren's line are related to:(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

Ohngren's line and classification are specifically related to maxillary sinus carcinoma. The Ohngren's line is an imaginary line drawn from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible, dividing the maxillary sinus into antero-inferior and postero-superior halves. This classification helps determine prognosis of maxillary sinus tumors - those occurring in the postero-superior portion have worse prognosis than those in the antero-inferior portion. This classification system is important for surgical planning and prognostication in maxillary sinus malignancies.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebellopontine angle tumor: These tumors are classified using the Koos grading system based on size and compression of brainstem. Ohngren's classification is not used for these posterior fossa tumors.

 

Option C. Glomus Jugulare Tumor: These paragangliomas are classified using the Glasscock-Jackson classification or the Fisch classification systems, which are based on tumor extent and invasion. Ohngren's classification has no role in these tumors.

 

Option D. Basal Cell Carcinoma of eyelid: These skin malignancies are classified using TNM staging or histological patterns (nodular, superficial, morpheaform, etc.). Ohngren's line and classification are specifically for maxillary sinus tumors, not skin malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ohngren's line divides the maxillary sinus into prognostically significant regions, with tumors posterior-superior to this line having worse prognosis due to proximity to vital structures like orbit, skull base, and pterygomaxillary fossa.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is diagnosed with osteosarcoma and is scheduled to undergo chemotherapy as part of his treatment. Methotrexate is included in his chemotherapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of his osteosarcoma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR.

 

Methotrexate has different mechanisms for anticancer activity and for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

 

Mechanism in Osteosarcoma (As anticancer drug): Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate interferes with the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, an essential cofactor for DNA synthesis. This leads to a decrease in DNA and RNA synthesis, thereby arresting the cell cycle and inhibiting the growth of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells in osteosarcoma.

 

Mechanism in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): Methotrexate is used at much lower doses in Rheumatoid Arthritis. In this condition, the major mechanism involves the inhibition of an enzyme called AICAR transformylase, part of the purine synthesis pathway. When AICAR transformylase is inhibited, levels of AICAR (5-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide ribonucleotide) accumulate in the cell. This leads to an inhibition of another enzyme called adenosine deaminase, which is responsible for the degradation of adenosine. As a result, adenosine levels increase within the cell and in the extracellular environment. Adenosine is known to have anti-inflammatory properties. When adenosine interacts with its receptors, it can lead to various effects such as inhibition of inflammatory cell function, vasodilation, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine release. These actions contribute to the anti-inflammatory effects observed when methotrexate is used for treating RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Analog of UMP: Methotrexate is not an analog of UMP (uridine monophosphate). It does not exert its effects through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Blocks purine synthesis: Methotrexate does not specifically block purine synthesis, although the inhibition of DHFR indirectly affects purine and pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Option D. Blocks pyrimidine synthesis: Similar to Option C, methotrexate does not specifically block pyrimidine synthesis but indirectly affects it through DHFR inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate's primary mechanism of action in treating osteosarcoma is as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which interferes with DNA synthesis and cell division in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: Anticancer drug that can result in hand and foot syndrome is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Capecitabine

 

Capecitabine is an oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), and both of these drugs are known to cause hand-foot syndrome (palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia). This condition is characterized by redness, swelling, and pain on the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It occurs due to the leakage of the drug from capillaries in these areas, leading to skin toxicity. Hand-foot syndrome is a well-documented adverse effect of capecitabine, making it the correct answer in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is associated with a different side effect profile, most notably hemorrhagic cystitis, which can be prevented by the administration of mesna.

 

Option B. Bleomycin: Bleomycin is known to cause pulmonary fibrosis and can also result in flagellated pigmentation of the skin.

 

Option C. Paclitaxel: Paclitaxel is an anticancer drug that primarily causes peripheral neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capecitabine & 5FU can cause hand-foot syndrome, which is an important side effect to monitor in patients receiving this treatment.

questions.text: A tuberculosis patient receiving anti-tubercular treatment complains of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs. He is not diabetic and drinks alcohol on occasion. Which of the following vitamins should be given to this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

The patient's symptoms of tingling and paresthesia in the lower limbs, in the context of receiving anti-tubercular treatment, are suggestive of peripheral neuropathy. One of the mainstays of tuberculosis (TB) treatment includes the drug isoniazid, which is known to cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency. Supplementing with vitamin B6 can prevent or alleviate these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy, it is not typically associated with anti-tubercular therapy. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more commonly linked to conditions like pernicious anemia or dietary deficiencies.

 

Option C. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency of vitamin B2 can lead to various symptoms, including skin disorders and anemia, but it is not specifically linked to the type of neuropathy seen in patients taking isoniazid for TB.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Deficiency of vitamin B3 leads to pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia, and is not associated with the peripheral neuropathy observed in patients on isoniazid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients receiving isoniazid as part of anti-tubercular therapy should be supplemented with vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) to prevent or treat peripheral neuropathy, a common side effect of this medication.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cetuximab 

 

Cetuximab is a monoclonal antibody against EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor). It is used in the treatment of Colorectal and Head and Neck Cancers. It is not an immune check point inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and are used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option B. Pembrolizumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor

- 1 (PD-1) and are used for the treatment of advanced melanoma.

 

Option C. Atezolimumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor. It acts by inhibiting programmed death-ligand - 1 (PDL-1) and is used for the treatment of urothelial, breast and non-small cell lung cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important immune check point inhibitors include:

 

New:                Nivolumab

Drugs:              Durvalumab

Act:                  Avelumab

At:                   Atezolizumab

Immune:          Ipilimumab

Check:             Cemiplimab

Point:               Pembrolizumab

questions.text: A woman at 8 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with hyperthyroidism. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propylthiouracil

 

During the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism. This preference is due to the fact that PTU has a lower risk of causing birth defects compared to Methimazole, which is associated with a rare but serious condition called aplasia cutis (a congenital skin defect). PTU is considered safer in early pregnancy, especially during organogenesis (the first trimester), as it crosses the placenta less readily than Methimazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methimazole: Methimazole is typically avoided during the first trimester because it is associated with teratogenic effects, particularly the risk of aplasia cutis and other congenital abnormalities.

 

Option B. Carbimazole: Carbimazole is a prodrug that is converted to Methimazole in the body. Like Methimazole, it is also avoided during the first trimester due to the risk of congenital defects.

 

Option D. Radioactive iodine: Radioactive iodine is contraindicated in pregnancy at any stage, as it can destroy fetal thyroid tissue, leading to permanent hypothyroidism in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the first trimester of pregnancy, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred treatment for hyperthyroidism due to its lower risk of causing birth defects compared to other antithyroid medications.

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopic image of the lung tissue. A patient infected with SARS-COV2 presents with ARDS. The infection would affect and expand which of the labelled layers? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A  

 

The image given in the question demonstrates the electron microscopic image of the blood-air barrier in the lungs. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has been set in this patient with COVID-19. Damage to the endothelial (Labelled as A, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage. Neutrophils play a significant role in tissue injury in this condition.

 

 

 

The electron micrograph shows at high magnification three components of the air-blood barrier in the alveolar septum. Gaseous exchange occurs across, 1) the cytoplasm of a type I alveolar cell or pneumocyte, P1; 2) the fused basal laminas (basement membranes) of type I alveolar and endothelial cells, BM; and 3) the cytoplasm of an endothelial cell, E, enclosing a blood capillary. Note the erythrocyte, Er, present within the lumen of the blood capillary. A fourth component of the air-blood barrier, surfactant, is not preserved in routine histological sections.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Basement Membrane: While the basement membrane is part of the blood-air barrier, it is not the primary site of injury in ARDS.

 

Option C. Type I Alveolar cell/Pneumocyte: Although these cells are affected in ARDS, the endothelial cells are typically the first to be damaged.

 

Option D. Erythrocyte: The erythrocyte is not structurally affected by ARDS but rather suffers the consequences of impaired gas exchange due to endothelial and alveolar damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, especially in cases associated with SARS-CoV-2 infection, the primary injury occurs in the endothelial cells of the blood-air barrier, leading to inflammation, increased permeability, and subsequent respiratory failure.

questions.text: Which of the following can result in acute liver failure? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amanita phalloides toxicity

 

Among the given options, Amanita phalloides is the most direct and significant cause of liver damage. The toxins in this mushroom specifically target the liver and can lead to acute liver failure.

 

Amanita phalloides is a type of mushroom, commonly known as the death cap. It contains amatoxins, which are extremely toxic and can cause severe liver damage and failure. Amanita phalloides poisoning is a well-known cause of acute liver failure and is often cited in toxicology as a classic cause of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphate: These are chemicals commonly found in pesticides. They are known more for their neurotoxic effects due to inhibition of acetylcholinesterase. They can cause symptoms like pinpoint pupil, increase in secretions, diarrhea, urination and muscle weakness etc. Liver damage is not the primary concern with organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option B. Morphine: This is an opioid analgesic. Its main effects and side effects are on the central nervous system and gastrointestinal system. It can cause respiratory depression, constipation, and dependence, but it is not primarily known for causing liver damage.

 

Option C. Belladonna: Also known as deadly nightshade, contains atropine and scopolamine. These substances can cause anticholinergic syndrome, but they are not typically associated with liver damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amanita phalloides (death cap mushroom) is a well-known cause of acute liver failure due to its potent hepatotoxic amatoxins, making it a critical toxicological emergency.

questions.text: Which parameter is best used to monitor the adequacy of and guide fluid resuscitation in a patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Urine Output

 

Urine output is the best measure of organ perfusion and the best monitor for adequacy of fluid resuscitation.

 

Adequate end-organ perfusion is best indicated by urine output of >0.5 to 1 mL/kg/h. However, it does not give minute-to-minute values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CVP (central venous pressure): CVP is a poor reflector of preload. Central venous pressure (CVP) is the mean pressure in the superior vena cava, indicating right ventricular end-diastolic pressure or preload. Normal CVP ranges from 2 to 7 mm Hg (3 to 9 cm H20). A sick or injured patient with a CVP <3 mm Hg is presumed to be volume depleted and maybe given fluids with relative safety. However, CVP is unreliable for assessment of volume status or left ventricular function.

 

Option C. Blood pressure: Blood pressure is an important vital sign, but it alone may not provide a complete picture of a patient's fluid status. Hypotension (low blood pressure) can be a late sign of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and normotension (normal blood pressure) does not guarantee adequate tissue perfusion. The level of consciousness is an important marker for cerebral perfusion.

 

Option D. Oxygen saturation: Oxygen saturation (SpO2) measures the amount of oxygen in the blood, and while it is essential for assessing respiratory status, it is not a direct indicator of fluid balance or adequacy of fluid resuscitation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urine output is a valuable and non-invasive parameter for assessing fluid resuscitation. Adequate urine output indicates that the patient's kidneys are functioning well and that they are likely receiving an appropriate amount of fluids. It is a practical and real-time measure of the patient's response to fluid therapy.

questions.text: A patient with a previous history of myocardial infarction and ventricular arrhythmia is on treatment for the same since a few months. He developed fatigue, dyspnea, and weight gain. He had also developed pulmonary fibrosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

 

The drug that is responsible for the above-mentioned side effects is amiodarone.

 

Amiodarone

 

→ Longest acting [t1/2 → > 3 weeks] anti-arrhythmic drug

 

→ MOA →

  1. Na+ channel Blocker
  2. β-Blocker (Non-competitive)
  3. K+ channel Blocker [Main action]
  4. Calcium channel blocker

 

→ Indicated in all arrhythmias except Torsades de pointes

 

→ Adverse effect of amiodarone:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol is a Selective Beta 1 Blocker. C/I in Bradycardia, AV Block and Acute CHF. It is used in HTN, Classical angina, MI, Chronic CHF, Arrythmia

 

Option C. Aspirin: Aspirin is only irreversible COX Inhibitor, anti-platelet drug. C/I in child with viral infection (Due to Reye’s syndrome). Can cause Hyperuricemia at therapeutic doses - avoid in gout

 

Option D. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is classified under potassium-sparing diuretic. Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains the body's potassium levels. C/I in patients with hyperkalemia. Can cause gynecomastia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amiodarone is associated with a range of serious side effects, including pulmonary fibrosis, thyroid dysfunction, liver toxicity, and photosensitivity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

 

  • Clarithromycin is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 system, which is involved in the metabolism of many drugs, including digoxin. By inhibiting the metabolism of digoxin, clarithromycin can lead to elevated levels of digoxin in the blood, increasing the risk for digoxin toxicity.
  • Clarithromycin also acts as an inhibitor of the P-glycoprotein and can precipitate Digoxin toxicity. P glycoproteins are drug efflux pumps in the intestine that lead to a decrease in the bioavailability of drugs. Digoxin is one of the drugs that utilizes this mechanism for its metabolism. Therefore, the drugs which inhibit the Pgp can lead to the increased plasma concentration of Digoxin and lead to its toxicity.
  • Other drugs that inhibit the Pgp include 
    • Amiodarone
    • Verapamil
    • Diltiazem
    • Itraconazole
    • Propafenone
    • Flecainide 
    • Quinidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium chloride: This medication primarily affects potassium levels and has no significant interaction with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is not known to significantly interact with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option D. Triamterene: This diuretic medication primarily affects sodium and potassium levels and is not known to have a significant impact on digoxin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with hypertension is diagnosed with stage 4 chronic kidney disease, with eGFR of <30. His doctor wants to prescribe a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following can be given? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metolazone

 

In the context of a patient with stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of less than 30 mL/min, the choice of diuretic is important, as not all diuretics are effective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function. Among the thiazides, metolazone remains effective in presence of severe renal failure whereas traditional thiazides like chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide and chlorthiazide are ineffective.

 

The reason Metolazone remains effective in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD), where traditional thiazide diuretics are less effective, lies in their pharmacokinetic properties and the way they interact with kidney function.

 

Site of Action and Kidney Function:

 

  • Thiazide diuretics primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule in the kidney. They inhibit the sodium-chloride symporter, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, and consequently, water.
  • In advanced CKD, particularly when the eGFR (estimated glomerular filtration rate) falls below 30 mL/min, the kidney function is significantly impaired. Traditional thiazides become less effective because they depend on adequate kidney function to reach their site of action and to exert their diuretic effect.

 

Pharmacokinetics of Metolazone:

 

  • Metolazone is classified as a thiazide-like diuretic. Unlike traditional thiazides, it retains its effectiveness even in patients with reduced kidney function.
  • This is because metolazone has additional actions on the proximal tubule of the kidney, where it inhibits sodium reabsorption. This proximal action is not as dependent on kidney function as the action in the distal tubule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorothiazide: This traditional thiazide diuretic is ineffective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function (eGFR <30 mL/min).

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Another traditional thiazide diuretic that is not effective in advanced CKD due to its reliance on adequate kidney function to exert its diuretic effect.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Like other traditional thiazides, hydrochlorothiazide is ineffective in patients with severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metolazone is the preferred thiazide-like diuretic for patients with stage 4 chronic kidney disease and an eGFR of less than 30 mL/min, as it retains its effectiveness even in the presence of significantly reduced kidney function. This is due to its additional action on the proximal tubule, which is less dependent on kidney function.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for hairy cell leukemia? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cladribine

 

It is a purine analogue used in the treatment of Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Cladribine-phosphates interfere with DNA synthesis and repair through incorporation into DNA and through inhibition of enzymes involved in DNA metabolism, including DNA polymerase and ribonucleotide reductase.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & D are not used in Hairy cell leukemia.

 

Option C. Hairy cell leukemia patients have mutation in BRAF pathway and hence, Vemurafenib (BRAF inhibitor) is used as second line agent in refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cladribine remains the first-line treatment for hairy cell leukemia due to its high efficacy in inducing remissions.

choices.text: Concentration of the drug is 50% ionized and 50 % non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 90% ionized and 10% non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 75% ionized and 25 % non-ionized
Concentration of the drug is 25% ionized and 75 % non-ionized

questions.text: When the pH = pKa of a drug, which of the following statements is true? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Concentration of the drug is 50% ionized and 50 % non-ionized

 

As per the Henderson Hasselbach equation:

 

pH = pKa + log (Ionized form/Non-ionized form)

 

pKa of a drug is the pH at which 50% of the drug is ionized and 50% of the drug is non-ionized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the pH of the environment is equal to the pKa of the drug, the drug exists in a state where 50% is ionized and 50% is non-ionized. This is a critical concept in understanding drug solubility and absorption.

questions.text: Corticosteroid indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor is? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Betamethasone

 

Corticosteroids are used in pregnant females delivering premature babies in order to prevent Respiratory Distress Syndrome in the newborn due to inadequate levels of surfactants in the lungs of premature babies. Corticosteroids also reduce the chances of development of Necrotizing Enterocolitis and Intraventricular Hemorrhage in the newborn.

 

For this purpose, we can use either Dexamethasone or Betamethasone.

 

Dose:

 

  1. Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly x 4 doses
  2. Betamethasone 12mg 24 hourly x 2 doses

 

Total dose should be 24 mg in 48 hrs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrocortisone: Hydrocortisone is not typically used for fetal lung maturation. It is more commonly used for adrenal insufficiency and inflammatory conditions.

 

Option B. Triamcinolone: Triamcinolone is not indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation. It is primarily used for its anti-inflammatory effects in various conditions.

 

Option C. Methylprednisolone: Methylprednisolone is also not typically used for this purpose. It is often used for its potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties in various conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Betamethasone is the corticosteroid of choice for stimulating fetal lung maturation in preterm labor, administered to reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome and other complications associated with preterm birth.

questions.text: Isosorbide dinitrate is indicated for congestive heart failure in combination with which of the following vasodilators? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydralazine

 

Combining hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate (ISDN) is recommended for CHF.

 

The mechanism of action of hydralazine, a direct vasodilator, remains unknown. Moreover, it lowers nitrate tolerance. The combination of ISDN and hydralazine has been shown to have reduced mortality in patients of CHF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minoxidil: Minoxidil is a potent vasodilator used primarily for severe hypertension and not typically combined with ISDN for CHF.

 

Option C. Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily to treat subarachnoid hemorrhage and is not indicated for CHF.

 

Option D. Nitrendipine: Nitrendipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension but is not commonly used in combination with ISDN for CHF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate is indicated for the treatment of congestive heart failure, as it effectively reduces both preload and afterload, improving cardiac function and reducing symptoms and mortality in CHF patients.

choices.text: Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of colchicine? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Binds to tubulin and inhibits granulocyte migration

 

Colchicine is used in acute gout to control the inflammation. It acts by blocking the microtubules and thereby blocking the chemotaxis or migration of leucocytes. It leads to severe diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibits synthesis of uric acid: Drugs that inhibit the synthesis of uric acid include allopurinol and febuxostat, which inhibit the xanthine oxidase enzyme. Colchicine does not work by this mechanism.

 

Option B. Promotes excretion of uric acid: Uricosuric agents such as probenecid and sulfinpyrazone promote the excretion of uric acid. Colchicine does not promote the excretion of uric acid.

 

Option C. Inhibits xanthine oxidase enzyme: Allopurinol and febuxostat are drugs that inhibit xanthine oxidase, reducing the production of uric acid. Colchicine does not inhibit xanthine oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colchicine treats acute gout by binding to tubulin, inhibiting the polymerization of microtubules, and preventing the migration and chemotaxis of granulocytes. This reduces the inflammatory response associated with gout attacks.

questions.text: What is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Edrophonium

 

Edrophonium is a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that is used in the Tensilon test to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis. In patients with myasthenia gravis, the symptoms will improve following administration of edrophonium. In contrast, symptoms will worsen in a cholinergic crisis, indicating that the problem is excessive acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obidoxime: Obidoxime is primarily used to treat organophosphate poisoning and is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Option C. Donepezil: Donepezil is a long-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer's disease and is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug used to treat a variety of conditions, including poisoning by organophosphates and other substances that produce a cholinergic crisis. However, it is not used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Edrophonium is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from a cholinergic crisis by temporarily increasing acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, thereby improving symptoms in myasthenia gravis and worsening them in a cholinergic crisis.

choices.text: Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day

questions.text: The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tolvaptan

 

The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is to use tolvaptan.

 

Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist that works by blocking the action of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) in the kidneys, leading to increased urine output and improved serum sodium levels. It is currently the preferred treatment for chronic SIADH, as it has been shown to be effective in improving symptoms and reducing the risk of complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day is not a recommended approach to treating chronic SIADH, as it can lead to dehydration and other complications.

 

Option C. Demeclocycline, a tetracycline antibiotic, is another treatment option for SIADH, but it is less effective and has more side effects compared to tolvaptan.

 

Option D. Fludrocortisone, a mineralocorticoid hormone, is not recommended for the treatment of SIADH, as it can worsen hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and increase the risk of fluid retention.

 

Educational Objective:
