Tolvaptan is the best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH due to its selective antagonism of the vasopressin V2 receptor, leading to increased urine output and improved serum sodium levels. Other methods, such as severe fluid restriction and demeclocycline, are less effective or have more side effects. Fludrocortisone is not suitable for treating SIADH and can exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) was started on tolvaptan therapy. A few weeks later, he presents with symptoms of dry mouth and increased thirst. What is the likely mechanism behind these symptoms? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased free water clearance

 

Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist used in the management of ADPKD. By blocking the action of vasopressin at the V2 receptor, tolvaptan inhibits water reabsorption in the renal collecting ducts, leading to increased free water clearance (aquaresis). This can result in symptoms like dry mouth and increased thirst due to increased urine output and dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. V2 receptor agonism: Tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, not an agonist. Its mechanism of action is to block the V2 receptor, thereby increasing water excretion.

 

Option C. Increased renal cAMP levels: Vasopressin usually acts on the V2 receptor to increase cAMP levels, which in turn promotes water reabsorption in the collecting duct. Since tolvaptan is a V2 receptor antagonist, it would be expected to decrease cAMP levels in the kidney, not increase them.

 

Option D. Increase in urine osmolality: Tolvaptan's action leads to increased water excretion without a significant change in solute excretion, resulting in a decrease in urine osmolality, not an increase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolvaptan causes increased free water clearance by blocking V2 receptors, leading to symptoms of dehydration such as dry mouth and increased thirst. This is a direct result of its mechanism as a V2 receptor antagonist, which inhibits water reabsorption in the renal collecting ducts.

questions.text: Which is a mood stabilizer with an anti-suicidal role? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lithium

 

Lithium is the only mood stabilizer that has been consistently shown to have an anti-suicidal effect in patients with bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. Numerous studies have demonstrated that lithium reduces the risk of suicide and suicide attempts. It is considered the gold standard for mood stabilization, particularly in bipolar disorder, due to its efficacy in preventing both manic and depressive episodes.

 

Mechanism of Lithium:

 

  • Mood Stabilization: Lithium modulates neurotransmission by affecting various neurotransmitter pathways, including serotonin and norepinephrine.
  • Neuroprotective Effects: Lithium enhances neurogenesis and has neuroprotective effects, potentially contributing to its anti-suicidal properties.
  • Reduction in Aggression and Impulsivity: Lithium has been shown to reduce aggression and impulsivity, which are risk factors for suicide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder, particularly in patients with rapid cycling or mixed states. However, it does not have a proven anti-suicidal effect.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is effective as a mood stabilizer, particularly in preventing depressive episodes in bipolar disorder. While it helps in mood stabilization, it does not have a specific anti-suicidal effect.

 

Option D. Valproate: Valproate is another anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used in bipolar disorder, especially effective in rapid cyclers. It does not have an established anti-suicidal role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium is unique among mood stabilizers for its anti-suicidal properties. It significantly reduces the risk of suicide and is effective in stabilizing mood in patients with bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. Valproate is the drug of choice in rapid cyclers, whereas Lamotrigine is effective as a mood stabilizer in Depression.

questions.text: Rosuvastatin should not be combined with which of the following drugs? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Clarithromycin

 

  • Statins are metabolized by CYP3A4 enzyme, which is inhibited by clarithromycin. The plasma levels of statins may rise to high levels if used with clarithromycin, resulting in serious adverse effects like myopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxycodone: Oxycodone is an opioid analgesic used for pain management. It does not interact significantly with rosuvastatin and does not affect its metabolism.

 

Option C. Adalimumab: Adalimumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat autoimmune conditions. It does not interfere with the metabolism of rosuvastatin and therefore is not associated with increased risk of myopathy when used in combination.

 

Option D. Rivoraxaban: Rivaroxaban is an anticoagulant used to prevent and treat blood clots. It does not interact with the metabolism of rosuvastatin and does not pose a risk of increased myopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs increasing the risk of statin induced myopathy are:

 

  • Amiodarone
  • Gemfibrozil
  • HIV protease inhibitors like saquinavir, ritonavir etc.
  • Clarithromycin
  • Itraconazole

choices.text: It has rapid onset of action
It has less depressant action on heart
It has long duration of action
It causes less release of histamine

questions.text: Cis-atracurium is preferred over atracurium because? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It causes less release of histamine

 

Cis-atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent preferred over atracurium for several reasons:

 

  1. Histamine Release: Atracurium is known to cause histamine release, which can lead to hypotension and bronchospasm in susceptible individuals. Cis-atracurium, on the other hand, is a newer and more selective agent that causes less histamine release, making it safer and better tolerated.
  2. Metabolism: Atracurium is metabolized by plasma esterases, which can lead to variability in its effects. Cis-atracurium undergoes Hoffman elimination, a process that occurs at physiological pH and temperature, leading to more predictable and consistent metabolism, independent of organ function.
  3. Cardiovascular Effects: While both drugs have similar cardiovascular effects, the reduced histamine release with cis-atracurium minimizes the risk of hypotension and bronchospasm, which can be beneficial in patients with cardiovascular instability.
  4. Duration of Action: Cis-atracurium has a shorter duration of action compared to atracurium, which can be advantageous for titrating doses and facilitating recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It has rapid onset of action: The onset of action for cis-atracurium and atracurium is similar, so this is not the primary reason for preferring cis-atracurium over atracurium.

 

Option B. It has less depressant action on heart: Both drugs have similar cardiovascular effects, and the preference for cis-atracurium is not based on a difference in cardiac depression.

 

Option C. It has long duration of action: Cis-atracurium does not have a significantly longer duration of action compared to atracurium. In fact, its duration of action is similar or slightly shorter, allowing for easier titration and recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cis-atracurium is preferred over atracurium because it causes less histamine release, reducing the risk of side effects such as hypotension and bronchospasm, and it undergoes Hoffman elimination, which contributes to its safer profile and predictable metabolism.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in treatment of leprosy can result in hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

 

Clofazimine is known to cause hyperpigmentation of the skin. This drug is used in leprosy treatment for its anti-inflammatory properties and its ability to kill Mycobacterium leprae. Clofazimine can lead to a characteristic reddish-brown to black discoloration of the skin, which can be quite distressing to patients but is usually harmless.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is an antibiotic commonly used in the treatment of leprosy. While it has various side effects, hyperpigmentation is not typically associated with dapsone. Common side effects include hemolysis (especially in individuals with G6PD deficiency) and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that can be used as part of alternative regimens for leprosy. Hyperpigmentation is not a known side effect of ofloxacin. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendinitis.

 

Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is another cornerstone drug in the treatment of leprosy. It can cause orange-red discoloration of body fluids (such as urine, sweat, and tears), but it does not typically cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this case, the patient's hyperpigmentation is most likely due to clofazimine. This side effect is well-documented and is a result of the drug accumulating in the skin.

questions.text: Drug resistance is most commonly seen with which of the following infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

  • Gonorrhea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is notorious for developing resistance to multiple classes of antibiotics, including penicillins, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, and most recently, some strains have shown reduced susceptibility to cephalosporins and azithromycin. Drug-resistant gonorrhea is a significant public health challenge, and the CDC recommends dual therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin to address this issue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. While there have been cases of antibiotic resistance, it is not as prevalent or significant as in gonorrhea.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis (granuloma inguinale) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It is relatively rare, and drug resistance has not been a major issue in its treatment.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. While there are concerns about resistance to some antibiotics, such as macrolides, penicillin remains highly effective, and resistance is not as significant a problem as in gonorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, gonorrhea is the infection most commonly associated with drug resistance, making it a critical concern in the treatment of STIs.

questions.text: Which of the following pairings is incorrectly matched? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  D. Aromatase inhibitor - Triptorelin

 

Explanation:

 

Triptorelin is incorrectly matched as an aromatase inhibitor. Triptorelin is actually a GnRH agonist (Gonadotropin Releasing Hormone agonist) that, when administered continuously, leads to downregulation of pituitary GnRH receptors, resulting in suppression of FSH and LH release, and consequently decreasing testosterone and estrogen levels. Triptorelin is used in prostatic carcinoma, endometriosis, precocious puberty and uterine leiomyoma.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A. SERM - Raloxifene: This is a correct match. Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator that selectively acts as an estrogen agonist in bone and on lipid metabolism, but as an antagonist in endometrium and breast. It is used for prevention and treatment of osteoporosis and reduces the risk of breast cancer.
  • B. SERD - Fulvestrant: This is a correct match. Fulvestrant is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Down-regulator. It inhibits ER dimerization so that ER interaction with DNA is prevented and receptor degradation is enhanced. It's used for locally advanced or metastatic ER positive breast cancer that has stopped responding to tamoxifen.
  • C. Herceptin - Trastuzumab: This is a correct match. Herceptin is the brand name for trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Triptorelin is a GnRH agonist used in prostate cancer, endometriosis, and precocious puberty, while aromatase inhibitors (letrozole, anastrozole, exemestane) act by blocking the conversion of androgens to estrogens, making them useful in postmenopausal breast cancer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man from West Garo Hills district of Meghalaya presents to the Civil Hospital with intermittent fever, chills, and malaise. Laboratory findings confirm the diagnosis of uncomplicated P. vivax malaria. The region is known for its multidrug-resistant strains of P. falciparum and occasional mixed infections. Which of the following antimalarial regimens is considered the most appropriate first-line treatment for P. vivax malaria in this setting? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chloroquine followed by primaquine

 

Explanation:


For P. vivax malaria, the treatment strategy involves clearing the blood-stage parasites with chloroquine and eliminating the dormant liver hypnozoites with primaquine to prevent relapses. While the region is known for multidrug-resistant P. falciparum, chloroquine remains effective against P. vivax in most parts of India, including the North East.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Artemether plus lumefantrine – This is the first-line treatment for multidrug-resistant P. falciparum malaria, not for P. vivax malaria.

 

Option C: Artesunate plus Sulfadoxine plus Pyrimethamine – This combination is recommended for chloroquine-resistant P. falciparum malaria in most parts of India but is not used for P. vivax malaria.

 

Option D: Mefloquine – Mefloquine is sometimes used in multidrug-resistant P. falciparum cases, but it is not first-line therapy for P. vivax malaria.

 

Educational Objective:


P. vivax malaria requires a combination of blood schizonticidal treatment (e.g., chloroquine) and hypnozoitocidal therapy (e.g., primaquine) to ensure radical cure. Identifying the specific Plasmodium species and local resistance patterns is critical for choosing the appropriate antimalarial regimen.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of maraviroc, a drug used in the treatment of HIV? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Entry inhibition

 

Explanation:


Maraviroc is an entry inhibitor that works by selectively binding to the CCR5 co-receptor on the surface of CD4+ T cells. By doing so, it prevents the HIV virus from binding to this receptor, blocking its entry into host cells. Maraviroc is specifically effective against CCR5-tropic strains of HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition: This is the mechanism of drugs like remdesivir, used for RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2.

 

Option B. Reverse transcriptase inhibition: Reverse transcriptase inhibitors, such as tenofovir or efavirenz, block the enzyme responsible for converting viral RNA into DNA. This is not the mechanism of maraviroc.

 

Option C. Fusion inhibition: Fusion inhibitors, like enfuvirtide, block the fusion of the HIV viral envelope with the host cell membrane. This is different from maraviroc's mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:


Maraviroc acts as an entry inhibitor by blocking the CCR5 co-receptor, preventing the HIV virus from entering host cells. It is effective only in CCR5-tropic HIV and is part of targeted therapy in HIV management. Understanding the distinct mechanisms of antiretrovirals is essential for optimizing HIV treatment.

questions.text: The ECG of a patient who presented to the ER is as shown below. The patient was already given a carotid massage and IV Adenosine, but the blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg. The patient remains symptomatic with palpitations and mild dizziness. What is the next best step in management? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat Inj. adenosine 12 mg

 

Explanation:


In a hemodynamically stable patient with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), the next step after vagal maneuvers fail is to administer IV adenosine. The initial dose is 6 mg, followed by a repeat dose of 12 mg if the rhythm does not convert. Since the patient is stable with BP of 100/70 mmHg, pharmacological intervention with adenosine is the preferred approach before considering cardioversion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Synchronized cardioversion – Synchronized cardioversion is indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with tachyarrhythmias. This patient's BP and symptoms do not indicate instability, so cardioversion is unnecessary at this point.

 

Option C: Inj. amiodarone 300 mg – Amiodarone is typically reserved for ventricular arrhythmias or refractory cases of atrial arrhythmias. It is not the first-line treatment for SVT.

 

Option D: Oral beta-blocker – While beta-blockers may be useful for rate control in atrial tachyarrhythmias, they are not the treatment of choice for acute SVT.


Educational Objective:


In stable patients with SVT, adenosine is the drug of choice after vagal maneuvers fail. It effectively terminates most AV node-dependent tachyarrhythmias by temporarily blocking AV conduction. Synchronized cardioversion should be reserved for unstable cases with symptoms like severe hypotension, altered mental status, or chest pain.

questions.text: Dapsone acts as a folic acid synthesis inhibitor by competitively inhibiting the enzyme dihydropteroate synthase, which is essential for bacterial folic acid production. This mechanism underlies its therapeutic applications. Which of the following is not a primary therapeutic use of dapsone?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Viral infections

 

Dapsone is not effective against viruses because viruses do not rely on folic acid metabolism or dihydropteroate synthase for replication. Antiviral therapies typically target viral enzymes, replication mechanisms, or cellular entry processes, none of which involve dapsone's mechanism of action.

 

Dapsone’s mechanism of action involves the competitive inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase, which prevents the synthesis of dihydropteroic acid, a precursor in the folic acid pathway. This disruption in folic acid synthesis halts bacterial growth, explaining its use in:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leprosy: Dapsone is widely used to treat leprosy caused by Mycobacterium leprae, leveraging its bacteriostatic effects.

 

Option B. Fungal infections: Dapsone has applications in certain fungal infections, due to its folate pathway inhibition.

 

Option C. Immunomodulation: Dapsone has immunomodulatory properties, making it effective in treating inflammatory skin conditions like dermatitis herpetiformis, where it reduces neutrophil-mediated damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that dapsone acts as a folic acid synthesis inhibitor and is primarily used for conditions like leprosy, certain fungal infections, and immunomodulation. Dapsone has no therapeutic role in treating viral infections, as these organisms do not utilize the folic acid pathway targeted by the drug.

questions.text: Intravenous mannitol is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:


Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that works by increasing plasma osmolality, drawing fluid from intracellular and interstitial compartments into the vascular space. While this mechanism is beneficial in conditions like acute glaucoma, cerebral edema, and elevated intracranial pressure, it can exacerbate pulmonary edema by increasing intravascular volume and worsening fluid accumulation in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute glaucoma: Mannitol is frequently used to rapidly lower intraocular pressure in acute glaucoma by dehydrating the vitreous.

 

Option B. Cerebral edema: Mannitol is commonly used to reduce cerebral edema and lower intracranial pressure.

 

Option D. Elevated intracranial pressure: Mannitol is indicated to manage elevated intracranial pressure by drawing water out of the brain tissue into the vascular compartment.

 

Educational Objective:


Mannitol is contraindicated in conditions like pulmonary edema or congestive heart failure due to its potential to increase intravascular volume and exacerbate fluid overload. Careful patient selection is critical when using osmotic diuretics.
